entries: The honkatrice has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the honkatrice's allies is within 5 ft. of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw against being magically transformed. On a failed save, the creature begins to sprout feathers and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failed save, the creature is turned into a honkatrice until it goes at 0 hit points. A {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic turns the creature back to normal.

trait.name: Berserk
entries: Whenever the honkdra starts its turn with 80 hit points or fewer, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 6, the honkdra goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the honkdra attacks the nearest creature it can see. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the honkdra attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the honkdra goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The honkdra can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Multiple Heads
entries: The honkdra has five heads. While it has more than one head, the honkdra has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.
Whenever the honkdra takes 25 or more damage in a single turn, one of its heads dies. If all its heads die, the honkdra dies.

At the end of its turn, it grows two heads for each of its heads that died since its last turn, unless it has taken fire damage since its last turn. The honkdra regains 10 hit points for each head regrown in this way.

trait.name: Reactive Heads
entries: For each head the honkdra has beyond one, it gets an extra reaction that can be used only for {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

trait.name: Reflective Plumage
entries: The honkdra can't be affected or detected by spells of 1st level or lower unless it wishes to be. It has advantage on saving throws against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the honkdra sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The honkdra makes as many beak attacks as it has heads. Instead of attacking with the beak with a certain head, it can try to swallow with it.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) piercing damage. Once per turn, if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or become {@condition grappled} ({@dc 17} to escape).

action.name: Swallow
entries: The honkdra makes one bite attack against a Medium or smaller creature it is {@action grapple||grappling}. If the attack hits, the target takes the bite's damage, the target is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the honkdra, and it takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the honkdra's turns.

If the honkdra takes 25 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the honkdra must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 5 feet of the honkdra. If the honkdra dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 15 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Natural Invisibility
entries: The honkecho is {@condition invisible}. If it attacks or uses one of its actions, the honkecho stops being {@condition invisible} until the end of the current turn.

trait.name: Noise Absorption
entries: Whenever the honkecho is subjected to thunder damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the thunder damage dealt. However, the sonic overload excites the honkecho, who is immediately exposed to its own Perennial Cachonkphony (it makes the saving throw normally).

trait.name: Perennial Cachonkphony
entries: The honkecho constantly honks while it can see any creature and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. Each creature that starts its turn within 20 feet of the honkecho and can hear the honks must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature can't take reactions until the start of its next turn and rolls a {@dice d8} to determine what it does during its turn. On a 1 to 4, the creature honks, takes no action or bonus action and uses all its movement to move in a randomly determined direction. On a 5 or 6, the creature falls {@condition prone} and subtracts a {@dice d6} penalty to ability checks and attack rolls until the beginning of its next turn. On a 7 or 8, the creature makes a melee attack against a randomly determined creature within its reach or does nothing if it can't make such an attack.

trait.name: Sonic Movement
entries: The honkecho can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The honkecho makes two Maddening Honks attacks.

action.name: Maddening Honk
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d12}) psychic damage and 6 ({@damage 1d12}) thunder damage. A creature that goes to 0 hit points because of this damage develops a random {@table long-term madness|DMG} (see {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

action.name: Honkish Blast {@recharge 5}
entries: The honkecho emits a destructive goosish scream as a 50-foot cone. Each target in the cone or inside the honkecho's space makes a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw (with disadvantage if inside the honkecho's space). On a failed save, a target takes 26 ({@damage 4d12}) thunder damage. On a failed save of 5 or more, the target also becomes {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn, and permanently {@condition deafened} (potentially becoming able to ignore the Perennial Cachonkphony). On a success, a target takes half as much damage and none of the other effects. Effects that remove the {@condition deafened} condition, like the {@spell lesser restoration} spell, work as normal.

monster.name: Honkimera
languages: understands Abyssal and Draconic but can't speak

trait.name: Alertness
entries: The honkimera has a +5 bonus to its passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) (already included in the stat block).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The honkimera makes three attacks: one with its beak, one with its bite, and one with its horns. It can use its poisonous breath (if available) in place of its bite, or its honk of terror in place of its beak, or both.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Horns
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Honk of Terror
entries: Each creature of the Honkimera's choice that is within 60 feet of the Honkimera and can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. A creature that fails the saving throw becomes {@condition frightened} for 1 minute and immediately uses its reaction to move in a random direction. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Honkimera's Honk of Terror for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Poison Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon head exhales poisonous gas in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 31 ({@damage 9d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

monster.name: Honkraken
languages: understands Abyssal and Primordial but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Storm of the Honking Chaos {@recharge 5}
headerEntries: The honkraken casts the {@spell storm of the honking chaos|Honkonomicon}* spell without requiring components and using its Charisma as its spellcasting ability ({@dc 18}).

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The honkraken can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Freedom of Movement
entries: The honkraken ignores difficult terrain, and magical effects can't reduce its speed or cause it to be {@condition restrained}. It can spend 5 feet of movement to escape from nonmagical restraints or being {@condition grappled}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The honkraken has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The honkraken deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The honkraken makes two Tail attacks, each of which it can replace with one use of Fling.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} ({@dc 22} to escape). If the target is a Large or smaller creature and is already {@condition grappled} by the honkraken, that creature is swallowed, and the {@action grapple} ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the honkraken, and it takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the honkraken's turns. If the honkraken takes 40 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the honkraken must succeed on a {@dc 23} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the honkraken. If the honkraken dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse using 15 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 22}). Until this {@action grapple} ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. The honkraken can {@action grapple} only one target with its tail.

action.name: Fling
entries: One Large or smaller object held or creature {@condition grappled} by the honkraken is thrown up to 60 feet in a random direction and knocked {@condition prone}. If a thrown target strikes a solid surface, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Filth Cloud (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The honkraken expels filth in a 50-foot radius cloud that spreads around corners. Underwater, this area is heavily obscured to creatures other than the honkraken. A creature other than the honkraken that is currently in the area or that ends its turn there must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 13 ({@damage 2d12}) poison damage and becomes {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and is not {@condition poisoned}. A strong wind or current disperses the cloud, which otherwise disappears at the end of the honkraken's next turn.

legendary.name: Primordial Honks of Madness (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The honkraken targets any number of creatures currently inside or within 5 feet of the area of Storm of the Honking Chaos with a chilling, primordial magical honk from the dawn of time. Each target makes a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 13 ({@damage 2d12}) psychic damage and becomes {@condition frightened} of the honkraken for 1 minute. A creature that is reduced to 0 hit points while {@condition frightened} in this way develops a {@table long-term madness|DMG} (see {@book Chapter 8 of the Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG|8}). A creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

legendary.name: Tail Attack or Fling
entries: The honkraken makes one tail attack or uses its Fling.

trait.name: Goosifying Gaze
entries: When a creature that can see the megoosa's eyes starts its turn within 30 ft. of the megoosa, the megoosa can force it to make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw if the megoosa isn't {@condition incapacitated} and can see the creature. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the creature is instantly turned into a goose ({@creature domestic goose|Honkonomicon|domestic} or {@creature wild goose|Honkonomicon|wild}, DM's choice). Otherwise, a creature that fails the save begins to magically transform in a random way and has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls until the beginning of its next turn. Roll a {@dice d4}:

items: The target's feet become webbed. Its speed is halved, but gains a swim speed equals to its basic speed.

The target's head becomes the one of a goose. It can't speak or cast spells with verbal component, but can make unarmed attacks with the beak that deal {@damage 1d4} damage plus its Strength modifier.
The target's arms become goose wings. The target drops everything that it's holding and has no hands anymore, but gains a flying speed of 15 feet.
The target grows feathers all over its body. It has disadvantage on Dexterity checks (including initiative) but makes all saving throws against cold with advantage.

entries: The third time that a creature would receive one of these transformations, it transforms into a {@creature wild goose|Honkonomicon} instead. These transformations are a curse that lasts until the creature is freed by the {@spell remove curse} spell or other magic. One use of the spell reverts all of these transformations.

Unless {@status surprised}, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the medusa until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the megoosa in the meantime, it immediately makes the save.
If the megoosa hears a honk within 30 ft. of it, the megoosa is affected by its own gaze if the source of the honk makes a successful {@dc 20} Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check as an action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The megoosa makes either two attacks, only one of which can be with its goose hair.

action.name: Goose Hair
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}17 ({@damage 6d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Quill Throw
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage plus 6 ({@damage 1d12}) force damage.

monster.name: Mother Goose
languages: and can speak and understand any goose creature

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Mother Goose casts one of the following spells, requiring only verbal component and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 16}):

spellcasting.name: Summon Fine Gander (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
headerEntries: Mother Goose casts {@spell find giant goose steed|Honkonomicon}* with only verbal component as an action. The giant goose summoned in this way is always a {@creature Giant Goose Steed (Great Golden Goose)|Honkonomicon|celestial gander} and doesn't go into a confused frenzy when it rolls a 1. The celestial gander has half the maximum hit points of Mother Goose.

trait.name: Grandma's Awareness
entries: The Mother Goose knows if it hears a lie.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the Mother Goose fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Mother Goose makes two attacks with her Scolding Cane. She can use her Nursery Rhyme (if available) instead of one of these attacks.

action.name: Scolding Cane
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage and 11 ({@damage 2d10}) psychic damage, and the target has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Nursery Rhyme {@recharge 4}
entries: Mother Goose recites one of her famous nursery rhyme, creating one of the following effects at her choice:

items.name: Fictional World
items.entry: Mother Goose generates an illusion as per the {@spell major image} spell that Mother Goose can command or use to attack as a bonus action. If the illusion represents something harmful and Mother Goose wishes so, a creature that touches the illusion makes a {@dc 16} Intelligence save, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) psychic damage on a failed save.

items.name: Good Warning
items.entry: Mother Goose chooses up to three creatures that can hear her within 60 feet. Each of the targets gain a {@dice d8} {@classFeature bardic inspiration|Bard|PHB|1|PHB} die (see {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}) that can be used until their next long rest.

items.name: Ominous Warning
items.entry: Mother Goose chooses any number of targets that can hear her within 60 feet of her. Each target makes a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw, becoming {@condition frightened} on a failed save. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

bonus.name: Shapechanger
entries: Mother Goose can use its bonus action to polymorph into a Medium {@creature domestic goose|Honkonomicon} or {@creature wild goose|Honkonomicon}, or back into its true form. Its statistics, other than its size and speed, are the same in each form and Mother Goose can still speak even as a goose. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

legendary.name: Bring the Story to Life
entries: The Mother Goose manipulates an illusion created with her Nursery Rhyme. She can attack with the illusion, (making a melee or ranged spell attack with {@hit 8}, with a range of 30 feet) dealing 11 ({@damage 2d10}) psychic damage on a hit.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Mother Goose uses Spellcasting.

legendary.name: Goose Flight (Only While Riding a Goose Creature)
entries: Mother Goose moves with her mount up to the mount's flying speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

legendary.name: Morale of the Story
entries: Mother Goose explains the moral of the story to a creature that is affected by her Nursery Rhyme in one of the following ways: is currently {@condition frightened}, is holding one of her {@classFeature bardic inspiration|Bard|PHB|1|PHB} dice or has interacted with her Fictional World illusion since Mother Goose's last turn. The target gains advantage or disadvantage on its next attack roll, ability check or saving throw or 5 temporary hit points (Mother Goose's choice).

variant.name: Summon Mother Goose's Guardian
entries: With this variant, Mother Goose can summon a celestial guardian to protect her against any threat.

entries.name: Summon Mother Goose's Guardian (1/Day)
entries: Mother Goose summons a shining avian celestial as per the {@spell summon goose guardian|Honkonomicon}* spell, without requiring {@status concentration}. She can only summon the {@creature Goose Spirit (Honking Defender)|Honkonomicon|Honking Defender} in this way, and uses her Charisma as her spellcasting ability and her proficiency bonus when required by the spell (spell attack {@hit 8}).

variant.name: Eyeglasses of Mother Goose
entries: Mother Goose might be carrying her iconic {@item Eyeglasses of Mother Goose|Honkonomicon}, a legendary magic item that you can find in this book. If she does so, she gains the following benefits while wearing and being attuned at them:

items: Mother Goose has advantage on Intelligence, Wisdomand Charisma saving throws.

Mother Goose gains proficiency with {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Nature} and {@skill Religion}. When making an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check she treats a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10. She can spend 10 minutes telling beautiful stories and nursery rhymes to up to eight friendly creatures (which can include herself) within 30 feet of her who can see or hear her and who can understand her. Each creature has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} for 1 hour. This ability can't be used again until the next dawn. She can cast the cantrip {@spell guidance} at will.

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: Mother Goose might be carrying her iconic {@item Eyeglasses of Mother Goose|Honkonomicon}, a legendary magic item that you can find in this book. If she does so, she gains the following benefits while wearing and being attuned at them:

items: Mother Goose has advantage on Intelligence, Wisdomand Charisma saving throws.

Mother Goose gains proficiency with {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Nature} and {@skill Religion}. When making an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check she treats a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10. She can spend 10 minutes telling beautiful stories and nursery rhymes to up to eight friendly creatures (which can include herself) within 30 feet of her who can see or hear her and who can understand her. Each creature has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} for 1 hour. This ability can't be used again until the next dawn. She can cast the cantrip {@spell guidance} at will.

items.name: Summon Mother Goose's Guardian (1/Day)
headerEntries: Mother Goose summons a shining avian celestial as per the {@spell summon goose guardian|Honkonomicon}* spell, without requiring {@status concentration}. She can only summon the {@creature Goose Spirit (Honking Defender)|Honkonomicon|Honking Defender} in this way, and uses her Charisma as her spellcasting ability and her proficiency bonus when required by the spell (spell attack {@hit 8}).

1e: {@spell summon goose guardian|Honkonomicon} ({@creature Goose Spirit (Honking Defender)|Honkonomicon|Honking Defender} only)

monster.name: Primal Honkecho
senses: blindsight 30 ft. ({@condition blinded||blind} beyond this radius)

trait.name: Echo of Chaos
entries: Whenever a creature within 100 feet of the honkecho (including the honkecho itself) rolls a natural 1 on an ability check, attack roll or saving throw, it generates a random effect from the {@table wild magic surge|PHB|wild magic table} (see {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}).

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the honkecho fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Natural Invisibility
entries: The honkecho is {@condition invisible}. If it attacks or uses one of its actions, the honkecho stops being {@condition invisible} until the end of the current turn.

trait.name: Noise Absorption
entries: Whenever the honkecho is subjected to thunder damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the thunder damage dealt. However, the sonic overload excites the honkecho, who is immediately exposed to its own Perennial Cachonkphony (it makes the saving throw normally).

trait.name: Perennial Cachonkphony
entries: The honkecho constantly honks while it can see any creature and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. Each creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the honkecho and can hear the honks must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature can't take reactions until the start of its next turn and rolls a {@dice d8} to determine what it does during its turn. On a 1 to 4, the creature honks, takes no action or bonus action and uses all its movement to move in a randomly determined direction. On a 5 or 6, the creature falls {@condition prone} and subtracts a {@dice d6} penalty to ability checks and attack rolls until the beginning of its next turn. On a 7 or 8, the creature makes a melee attack against a randomly determined creature within its reach or does nothing if it can't make such an attack.

trait.name: Sonic Movement
entries: The honkecho can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The honkecho makes three Maddening Honk attacks, or one against each target within reach.

action.name: Maddening Honk
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) psychic damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) thunder damage. A creature that goes to 0 hit points because of this damage develops a random {@table long-term madness|DMG} (see {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

action.name: Honkish Blast {@recharge 5}
entries: The honkecho emits a destructive goosish scream as a 60-foot cone. Each target in the cone or inside the honkecho's space makes a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw (with disadvantage if inside the honkecho's space). On a failed save, a target takes 58 ({@damage 9d12}) thunder damage. On a failed save by 5 or more, the target also becomes {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn, and permanently {@condition deafened} (potentially becoming able to ignore the Perennial Cachonkphony). On a success, a target takes half as much damage and none of the other effects. Effects that remove the {@condition deafened} condition, like the {@spell lesser restoration} spell, work as normal.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The honkecho makes an attack with its Maddening Honk.

legendary.name: Cachonkphonical Echo
entries: The honkecho targets a creature currently under the effect of the Perennial Cachonkphony. The target takes 13 ({@damage 2d12}) psychic damage, then suffers another random effect from the ability (roll a {@dice d8}).

legendary.name: Fast as Sound
entries: The honkecho moves up to double its speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

trait.name: Alertness
entries: The rhonk has a +5 bonus to its passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) (already included in the stat block).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The roc makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 8}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until this {@action grapple} ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the roc can't use its talons on another target.

action.name: Thunderous Honk {@recharge 5}
entries: The rhonk emits a honk of unbelievable magnitude, resounding with the same strength of multiple thunders. Each target in a 90-foot cone makes a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 55 ({@damage 10d10}) thunder damage and becomes {@condition deafened}. On a failed save by 5 or more, the target is also {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a target takes half as much damage and none of the other negative effects above.

Additionally, every unattended object of size Large or smaller is pushed to the bottom of the area and takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage per each 10 feet of movement. A creature on the trajectory of such an object must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking that same damage on a failed save.

monster.name: Ur-Goose

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Ur-goose casts one of the following spells, requiring only verbal component and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 25}):
will: {@spell animal friendship} (goose beasts have no save)

spellcasting.name: Honk of Liberation
headerEntries: The Ur-goose casts the {@spell dispel magic} or {@spell remove curse} spell with only verbal component, using Charisma as its spellcasting ability.

trait.name: Elemental Nature
entries: The Ur-goose doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Elemental Restoration (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the Ur-goose would be reduced to 0 hit points, its current hit-point total instead resets to 350 hit points, it recharges its Honktropy, and it regains any expended uses of Legendary Resistance. Additionally, the Ur-goose can now use the options in the "Mythic Actions" section for 1 hour. Award a party an additional 90,000 XP (180,000 XP total) for defeating the Ur-goose after its Elemental Restoration activates.

trait.name: Honkhaotic Aura
entries: At the beginning of the Ur-goose's turn, one of the following random effects affects the area within 60 feet of the Ur-goose (including itself). Each effect lasts until the beginning of the Ur-goose's next turn. Roll a {@dice d4}:

items.name: 1: Honkfusion
entries: Creatures in the area are affected by the {@spell confusion} spell ({@dc 25}) and gain vulnerability to psychic damage.

items.name: 2: Magical Havonk
entries: Each creature failing a {@status concentration} check or rolling a 1 on the {@dice d20} for any ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, triggers a {@table wild magic surge|PHB|wild magic effect} (see {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}). Creatures have vulnerability to force damage.

items.name: 3: Web Limbs
entries: Each creature in the area is targeted by the {@spell web limbs|Honkonomicon}* spell ({@dc 25}). Creatures have vulnerability to necrotic damage.

items.name: 4: Honkquake
entries: Each creature in the area makes a {@dc 25} Strength saving throw to not be knocked {@condition prone}. Creatures have vulnerability to thunder damage. The area becomes difficult terrain.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the Ur-goose fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Wildest of All Geese
entries: The Ur-goose can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing, ignores difficult terrain, and can ignore any effect that changes its shape, limits its actions or movement, or that banishes or imprisons it, like the {@spell banishment}, {@spell imprisonment}, and {@spell maze} spells.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Ur-goose attacks three times with its Beak of Chaos, Debris Throw, or a combination of the two.

action.name: Beak of Chaos
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) piercing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) force damage, or the last type of damage dealt by Honktropy in the last hour instead of force. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}). Until this {@action grapple} ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the Ur-goose can't beak another target.

action.name: Debris Throw
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 15} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 3d12 + 7}) bludgeoning damage (or other type based on the kind of materials thrown). A creature makes a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw to not be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Honktropy {@recharge 4}
entries: The Ur-goose emits a random primordial honk that chaotically reorganizes the rules of matter and reality in a 100-foot cone. A target can willingly fail the saving throw. Unless stated otherwise, any effect that is not damage lasts until the target rolls a 1 or 20 on the {@dice d20} for an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw and can be removed with the {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic. Roll a {@dice d6}:

items.name: 1: Booming Honk
entries: Each target within the area makes a {@dc 25} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 65 ({@damage 10d12}) thunder damage, becomes {@condition deafened} but gains resistance to thunder damage. On a success, it takes half as much damage and is not {@condition deafened}. On a failed save by 5 or more, it is also {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn and the target's ears fall off. The area becomes difficult terrain until cleared out.

items.name: 2: Dechonkposition
entries: Each target in the area makes a {@dc 25} Constitution saving throw, taking 65 ({@damage 10d12}) necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success. On a failed save, the creature is also {@condition poisoned}, but gains resistance to necrotic, poison, and radiant damage. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turn, ending the {@condition poisoned} condition on a success.

items.name: 3: Honk of Nature
entries: Each target in the area is being wrapped by poisonous vines and makes a {@dc 25} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 65 ({@damage 10d12}) poison damage and becomes {@condition restrained}, but can be freed with a {@dc 19} Dexterity or Strength check as an action. On a failed save, the target also regains 1 hit point at the beginning of each of its turns as long as it has at least 1 hit point left.

items.name: 4: Honkemental
entries: Each target in the area makes a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw, taking 71 ({@damage 11d12}) damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success. For the damage type roll a {@dice d4}: acid (1), cold (2), fire (3), or lightning (4). Each target that failed the save also gains resistance to another type or random damage (roll the {@dice d4} again).

items.name: 5: Pshonkedelich
entries: Each creature in the area makes a {@dc 25} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 65 ({@damage 10d12}) psychic damage and subtracts the result of a {@dice d6} to its ability checks and attack rolls, but gains advantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws and experiences visions that grant it inspiration. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

items.name: 6: Space-Bending Honk
entries: Each target within the area makes a {@dc 25} Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 52 ({@damage 8d12}) force damage and is teleported to a random direction within 40 feet, but gains a flying speed of 30 feet. On a success, it takes only half as much damage and none of the other effects above.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Ur-goose makes a Beak of Chaos or Debris Throw attack.

legendary.name: Wild Goose Chase (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Ur-goose moves up to its speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}. At any point during this movement, the Ur-goose can use the {@action Hide} action even while in plain sight, cast the {@spell invisibility} spell, or both.

mythicHeader: If the Ur-goose's Elemental Restoration trait has activated in the last hour, she can use the options below as legendary actions.

mythic.name: Dishonktegration
entries: A creature that the Ur-goose can see within 120 feet of it makes a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw. The creature takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) force damage and one level of {@condition exhaustion} on a failed save, or 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage and no {@condition exhaustion} on a success.

mythic.name: Goosification (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: A creature currently {@condition grappled} by the Ur-goose makes a {@dc 25} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it is magically transformed into a {@creature wild goose|Honkonomicon}*, or takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) force damage on a success. A {@spell dispel magic} or {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic ends the effect.

variant.name: Summon Goose Creature
entries: Being the creator entity of most goose creatures, the Ur-goose can have an action option that allows it to summon others of its kind.

entries.name: Summon Goose Creature (1/Day; Recharges After Elemental Reassemblement)
entries: The Ur-goose performs one of the following magical summonings.

items: {@dice 2d6} {@creature wild goose|Honkonomicon|geese}, {@creature giant goose|Honkonomicon|giant geese} or {@creature flock of geese|Honkonomicon|flocks of geese}
{@dice 1d4} {@creature gray honker|Honkonomicon|gray honkers}
{@dice 1d8} {@creature grifoose|Honkonomicon|grifooses}
{@dice 1d8} {@creature honkatrice|Honkonomicon|honkatrices}
{@dice 1d6} {@creature honkdra of the ponds|Honkonomicon|honkdras of the ponds}
{@dice 1} {@creature honkraken|Honkonomicon} (can't use legendary actions, but can use them as regular actions)
{@dice 1d3} {@creature rhonk|Honkonomicon|rhonks}
{@dice 2d6} {@creature weregoose|Honkonomicon|weregeese}

entries: A summoned creature appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of the Ur-goose, acts as its ally, and can't summon other creatures. It remains for 1 minute, until the Ur-goose dies, or until it dismisses it as an action.

variant.name: Mythic Variant: Flockification
entries: With this variant, the Ur-goose divides itself into four other geese after using its Elemental Restoration. The creature gains the following trait:

entries.name: Flockification
entries: When using its Elemental Restoration, the Ur-goose splits into four Huge clones of itself, all within a 60 feet range from each other. Each clone has 84 hit points and shares the same initiative order. The Ur-goose has only one pool of actions, legendary actions and legendary resistances, but can use them through any of its clones (if the Ur-goose spends a legendary resistance on a saving throw made by more clones at the same time, it affects all of them). Every clone can still move and take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Dodge}, {@action Hide} or {@action Search} action independently.

After 1 hour, the remaining clones can reabsorb eachother (if two or more) while within 30 feet, and the Ur-goose can go back to normal. If there's only one clone left, the Ur-goose can just go back to normal after 1 hour.

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with silvered weapons

trait.name: Alertness
entries: The weregoose has a +5 bonus to its passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}).

trait.name: Hold Breath (Goose or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: The weregoose can hold its breath for 10 minutes.

action.name: Multiattack (Humanoid or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: The weregoose can use its Honk and then makes two attacks, only one of which can be a beak.

action.name: Beak (Goose or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be cursed with {@variantrule Player Characters as Weregeese|Honkonomicon|weregoose lycanthropy}.

action.name: Greatclub (Humanoid or Hybrid Form Only, while not Flying)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Honk (1/Day) (Goose or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: The weregoose honks aggressively towards a creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Shapechanger
entries: The weregoose can use its action to polymorph into a goose-humanoid hybrid or into a {@creature wild goose|Honkonomicon}, or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics, other than its size, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Alertness
entries: The goose has a +5 bonus to its passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) (already included in the stat block).

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The goose can hold its breath for 10 minutes.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Honk (1/Day)
entries: The goose honks aggressively towards a creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Lay Golden Egg (1/Day)
entries: The goose lays a golden egg (usually at dawn). The egg is worth 100 gp and can be used in place of any material component up to that value. A creature using the egg for evil or egoistic purposes might receive a curse, like the {@spell bestow curse} or {@spell web limbs|Honkonomicon}* spell, or one of the curses from {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1} (same DC of the Spellcasting action, if necessary).

While laying the egg, or later while touching it as an action, the goose can infuse one of its spells in the egg (including {@spell gooseance|Honkonomicon}*) that will trigger once at a condition established by the goose.

monsterFluff.name: Anserath, the Honking Chaos
entries: Anserath, the Honking Chaos, is the demon lord of anger and pointless destruction. Originally created by {@creature Pazuzu|MaBJoV} as his war dog, Anserath immediately fell out of control and ran away from its master. After doing so, the Honking Chaos first joined {@creature Demogorgon|MTF}, then abandoned him too to go on its own way. Now Anserath nests in the Seeping Woods of Yeenoghu's Realm, claiming no allegiance to any demon other than itself and frequently scouring through the Abyss in search for an excuse to move battle to anybody or anything.

The demon lord is also known as the Raging Mouths because of its insatiable desire to bite and eat anything on its trail. The dozens of goose heads composing Anserath's body are perpetually honking in a mixture of anger and hunger, and will never lose the chance to try to "taste" something in front of them. As primordial chaos flows strongly inside of the demon lord, creatures bitten by it can experience severe avian mutations that can eventually turn the victim into an actual {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}, a demonic goosish horror.
See {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1|Anserath, the Honking Chaos} for more information about Anserath.

entries.name: Anserath's Lair
entries: Anserath has a permanent nest in the Seeping Woods, on the layer of the Abyss known as Yeenoghu's Realm. However, the Honking Chaos is often wreaking havonk somewhere else and has the habit to temporarily nest wherever it's spending some time. The Raging Mouth's lair is a tangle of materials picked from its surroundings, and extremely foul.

entries.name: Fowlish Mutations
entries: When Anserath feeds upon a creature, it randomly twists and warps the creature's body to make it more and more in the demon lord's resemblance, until it become a horrifying {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}*. When this happens, roll on the {@table Fowlish Mutations|Honkonomicon} table. The {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic heals a mutation, as does a {@spell remove curse} spell casted by a goose creature.

monsterFluff.name: Demogoose
entries: One of the noisiest and filthiest spawns of the Abyss, the demogoose is a fiend that exists as the result of Anserath's chaotic corruption on another life-form. Since even just the mere vicinity of the Honking Chaos is enough to make any hatching egg generate a demogoose, these fowlish horrors follow the demon lord's path and are considered an ominous sign of its influence over a region.

These fire breathing fiends are considered hateful and undesirable even by demon standards, since when a demogoose shakes its wings to fly, it releases all kinds of filth around itself. Also the demon adores to terrorize the enemies with its honk and then jump on them, taking advantage of the terror and mayhem that it just induced.

Demogeese incarnate primordial chaos to the point of making it impossible to restrain them. This, added to the fact that they know no fear, is particularly frustrating for cultists or even more powerful demons that wish to control them for their purpose. Whoever ends up summoning a demogoose (willingly or by mistake) soon realizes that they are better employed as a tool to wreck pure havoc, than as part of any careful planning.

items.name: Demogoose of Many Mouths
entries: Being an embodiment of raw chaos, demogeese are destined to be constantly warping and evolving (if you can call it so) even more than other members of demonkind. A demogoose that survives long enough and eats plenty of living creatures can eventually become a demogoose of many mouths: a stronger, bigger and more horrifying incarnation of Anserath's wrath and hunger, and closer to the demon lord's unnatural shape.

When a demogoose of many mouths arrives in an area where other minor members of its kind are present, all regular demogeese (and possibly some other evil goose creatures) can start to follow it, forming a flock that is gonna try to nest in the area. Then they will try to steal eggs from other creatures that, when kept in the nest for long enough, will spawn brand new demogeese. If not destroyed in time, these fiendish nests can soon go out of control and become a very big, honking concern for everyone in the region.

items: Domestic geese are usually the result of a kind of selective breeding that gives them a heavier body, at the expense of their fly efficiency.

monsterFluff.name: Feathered Ooze
entries: This peculiar and particularly foul kind of ooze has adapted to live in places that are densely populated by geese or other avian creatures. The ooze adapted to look just like a pile of feathered waste, making it indistinguishable from the results of cleaning up a goose shed. A feathered ooze evolved to consider geese and similar creatures as a necessary part of its habitat, therefore doesn't usually attack them. In fact, it's not unknown for a farmer to be suddenly ambushed by one of these oozes while cleaning up a hen house.

The {@item Demonomicon of Iggwilv|TCE} claims that the first feathered ooze was generated after a battle between Anserath and Juiblex, as a result of the Honking Chaos feeding on the Faceless Lord's body and having an indigestion.

monsterFluff.name: Feathered Wrath
entries: Geese are renowned for getting angry fast. In certain cases,the anger of a goose can transcend life and death and transform it into an undead monster that is literally kept alive by its own bad intentions. This happens particularly often on geese that have been touched by the power of the demon lord Anserath, who can channel its rage through the bodies of other fellow geese so they can spread violence even beyond death.

When encountered, a feathered wrath will always attack on sight anything that moves. In fact, it is necessary for the monster to do so to stay alive, because being calm and reasonable can literally kill it. Even after being defeated, a feathered wrath can come back to life if there's still a battle inits vicinity, as it cannot resist the call for violence.

Feathered wraths love inflicting pain so much that they soon develop the habit to accumulate weapons and hide them within their feathers. Usually, a feathered wrath is encountered carrying about a half a dozen daggers, or any other weapon at the DM's choice.

images.credit: Polina Sokolova, edited by Simone Malvezzi

monsterFluff.name: Feathers Golem
entries: A feathers golem is an unusual implementation of the formula to create one of these artificial guardians. As opposed to other constructs that are made of more durable materials, a feathers golem is created when the crafter prefers adaptability to strength, or just has access to a great quantity of feathers (maybe because of the presence of other goose creatures). Its ability to pass through small cracks makes it ideal to guard places with particularly narrow corridors or natural caverns, and the capacity to attack with its feathers enables it to fight toe to toe with ranged opponents or even to control small groups of adversaries.
As it happens with other kinds of golems, this version can suffer from attacks of berserking rage, even aggravated by the presence of goose components as part of its body.

entries.name: Creation
entries: Crafting a feathers golem with a {@item manual of feathers golems|Honkonomicon|manual of golems created for this purpose} requires 20 days of work and 25,000 gp of supplies. See {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for the complete rules on how to use a {@item manual of golems}.

monsterFluff.name: Flock of Geese
entries: When in a group, geese can become even more noisy and aggressive. In normal situations, a flock of geese is (mostly) harmless, but its behavior can become erratic when a stronger goose creature is established in the region.

monsterFluff.name: Giant Goose
entries: A bigger, scarier and angrier member of goosedom, the giant goose has the habit of charging whoever perceives as an enemy (basically, everyone) while honking in the most terrifying way. Because of their heavy body, giant geese are not as suited at flying as other oversized birds (like {@creature giant eagle||giant eagles} and {@creature giant owl||giant owls}), however they compensate with a much greater amount of anger.

images.title: Sir Goose on his faithful giant goose steed

monsterFluff.name: Goose
entries: Geese are territorial and social creatures: they are very protective of who belongs to their group, and they will honk very loudly at whoever they perceive as trespasser. This, paired with the fact that they don't behave particularly well with strangers, makes them great guard animals.

monsterFluff.name: Goose of the Golden Feathers
entries: The fabled goose of the golden feathers (or golden goose) is a celestial child of the Great Golden Goose that exists with the purpose of helping the humbles and punishing the greedy ones. They can't speak, but will express themselves in very meaningful honks. Some temples of the Mother of Gold host a golden goose that is treated like a living saint and cared for with extreme care (some would say spoiled), as a form of respect for the goose's transcendent nature and in hope to maintain the goose's favor. Golden geese are usually pretty passive and lazy, even preferring to be carried around (as a form of respect for their divine nature, of course) other than flying or using their own legs. However, they won't hesitate to act if they witness cruelty, sparing none of their curses and beaks on whoever deserves them.

monsterFluff.name: Goose Skeleton
entries: Necromancers can turn geese into skeletons when they need a swimming undead that can chase off intruders or hunt down prey (or corpses) for them. Having no flesh, a goose skeleton lacks the ability to fly or honk (making it unusually silent for a goose) however their hollow bones make them particularly fast and agile. Since skeletons tend to repeat what they would be doing in life, goose skeletons have the unsettling habit to open their mouth into a silent honk, and can end up protecting the same territory or creature that they were attached to in life.

monsterFluff.name: Goose Zombie
entries: A goose zombie can rise when the corpse of a geese is infused with dark magic, purposely or by accident. Because of the goose's decomposing body, its honk will sound particularly hollow and distorted. Goose zombies are famous for trying to fly with their damaged wings that are often too decomposed to sustain them in the air.

monsterFluff.name: Gooseflayer Collective
entries: Mind flayers experimented on geese to turn them into waterborne scouts in service of their machiavellian plans.However the geese's chaotic nature, plus the stress from the constant telepathic honking, makes them particularly difficult to control for their illithid masters.

When a mind flayer colony makes the mistake of creating too many gooseflayers, these avian aberrations can rebel against their creators and form a peculiar form of psychically enhanced flock, called a gooseflayer collective. In this state, the bodies of all geese float by each other to form a perfect sphere with a single, fused mind that is, for all intended purposes, a whole creature in itself.

This is particularly threatening for a mind flayer colony, since the genius minds of the mutated geese can turn into a truly dangerous mastermind when fused together. For the stats of the individual {@creature gooseflayer|CircleoftheHonk|gooseflayers} and more information on them, see {@loader Circle of the Honk|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json} on the DMsGuild.

entries.name: One of Us
entries: The collective's objective is to rival an elder brain's power by becoming stronger (therefore ensuring that they can keep their freedom), so it needs to gather more and more geese to add to its cause (and to its spherical floating body). To achieve this, it will telepathically command all goose creatures in the area to find the collective and become one with it. The genius mind of the gooseflayers goes even beyond: in fact, why limit itself to "natural" geese? To ensure total assimilation, the aberration is able to mold the consciousness of any creature into the one of a goose, that they can then assimilate into the collective.

entries.name: A Gooseflayer Collective's Lair
entries: As opposed to its former masters, a gooseflayer collective doesn't suffer any aversion to sunlight. Therefore, it tends to choose the lair that is best for the collective's plans and objectives, possibly while staying out of reach of any illithid that might try to find the collective. The lair always includes a significant source of water, like a pond or a river, since it's important for the mental relief of the geese and, therefore, the well-being of the collective.

monsterFluff.name: Gray Honker
entries: A child of the Ur-goose inspired by the {@creature gray render|MPMM} (see {@book Monsters of the Multiverse|MPMM}), the gray honker embodies the most protective (and awkward) aspects of its landborn relative. While this monstrosity can be extremely dangerous and violent, it acts the most ferocious when in need to protect whoever considers "its flock", to the point of using its own body and wings as a living shield.

This avian giant can also perform its own peculiar version of the "dance" of the gray honker: a furious whirlwind of claw slashes, screeches and deafening honks made with the purpose of confounding the surrounding enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Great Golden Goose
entries: The timeless Great Golden Goose is widely considered the godmother of all goosekind and a symbol of freedom,prosperity and transcending enlightenment. While the Mother of Gold is a being of light and virtue, she's not to be mistaken as a passive entity, as both her and her children (the celestial {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon|geese of the golden feathers}) are famous for bestowing curses on whoever might deserve them.

An easy way to anger the Great Golden Goose is to abuse the gift delivered by her, act with excessive greed or hurt her "flock" or sacred temples. At the same time, she also embodies some of the most temperamental aspects of goosedom, making it easy to trigger her anger even with minor infractions. It is not unknown for a high rank cultist of the Great Golden Goose to go on a quest to find its patron, in the purpose to appease her rage (or at least understand the reason for it) after mysterious curses are being laid for apparently no reason.
See {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1} for more information about the lore, cults and powers of the Great Golden Goose.

entries.name: The Age-old Question
entries: Who came first, the egg or the goose? Not even the wisest sages know the answer. As much as nobody understands when and where the Great Golden Goose came to be, also none can say if she will ever find her end. When (and if) the Great Golden Goose dies or is destroyed, it comes back to life after one year and one day, hatching from one of the several golden eggs that exist in the world. For the first eighty-eight days of her life, she's indistinguishable from a {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon}* and has its same statistics. Then, suddenly, it will evolve into her final, divine incarnation of avian glory once more, while rewarding or punishing whoever treated her particularly kindly or cruelly in the meanwhile.
The only ways to stop the rejuvenation of the Great Golden Goose is to rid the multiverse of any golden egg (an almost impossible task) or to prevent her spirit from traveling freely after death.

entries.name: The Great Golden Gooses's Lair
entries: The Great Golden Goose follows a perpetual migration that begins in the Feywild, travels through each of the good-aligned planes (Ysgard, Arborea, the Beastlands, Elysium, Bytopia and Mount Celestia) and ends in in the Astral Sea. The migration is a metaphorical journey from passion to asceticism, starting in the planes that are more connected to strong emotions, and finishing in the ones that embody elevation and transcendence. The Goose has a nest in each of these planes, always in a location that's particularly remote and dangerous to reach.

images.title: A holy symbol of the Great Golden Goose

monsterFluff.name: Grifoose
entries: When the Ur-goose saw the mighty {@creature griffon}, it decided to tryout the same formula (with a personal twist, obviously) and created the grifoose. This goose-headed monstrosity has the same frightless spirit of the original, but pushed to the extreme of stupidity. In fact, a grifoose doesn't fear anything, even when it should.

Willingly or not, the Ur-goose managed to play a joke on every future creature that wished to ride its children, since the innate stubbornness of this monstrosity makes it extremely difficult to train and control it. More than once, a proud knight of the sky approaches a grifoose mistaking it for its more noble version, just to be thrown out of its saddle shortly after. However, a rider that learns how to deal with such a difficult mount, will be rewarded with a companion that doesn't run away even in front of the mightiest of dragons.

monsterFluff.name: Honkatrice
entries: Similar to a {@creature cockatrice} in many ways, a honkatrice is something between a lizard, a bat and a goose. These flying monstrosities share the same transformative powers of their similars, but with a twist: instead of turning creatures to stone, the bite of the honkatrice turns the victim into a honkatrice itself. This, added with the fact that these creatures act stronger when in groups, makes them particularly dangerous: one honkatrice can be enough to transform a whole village or more into a huge skein of these insidious honkers.

monsterFluff.name: Honkdra of the Ponds
entries: When the Ur-goose designed its avian creations, the honkdra was the concept on which the Primordial of Havonk experimented the most, giving birth to several variants of this multiheaded monstrosity. Aside from any variation, a honkdra is always a mockery of the infamous hydra, known to test the mettle of several great champions. The so called "honkdra of the ponds" is one of the smallest and weaker of its kind (and that's saying something), physically less threatening than a regular {@creature hydra} but with the habit of swallowing anything that moves, and a terrible attitude.

Inspired by the spawns of the blood of the dragon god Lernaea, slain by Tiamat at the dawn of time, the Ur-goose proceeded to craft a creature even more hateful and insidious, gifting to its children a kind of magical plumage that is even impervious to spells. Because of this, it can be particularly complicated for the adventurers to use fire to cauterize the cut heads of the honkdra, since they can't rely on fire cantrips.
For more versions of this creature, see {@loader Honkdra drom Lord of Eat|Lord of Eat; Honkdra.json} on DMsGuild.

monsterFluff.name: Honkecho
entries: When a group of geese that was particularly numerous (or angry) dies, it can leave behind a honkecho: the undead remains of their fowlish screams, resounding for eternity. This collective is made of pure sounds, as it is literally the honking of dozens of geese that constantly repeats itself, forever. The noise that comes from an honkecho is enough to confuse or drive most people crazy, and can shatter both matter and mind.

A honkecho is definitely noticeable through hearing, but {@condition invisible}. Only when it manifests its violent honks, it briefly becomes visible as a flash of spirits that resemble waves of sound.

monsterFluff.name: Honkimera
entries: Back in the days when Anserath was Demogorgon's pet and companion, the Prince of Demons gave birth to the {@creature chimera} to make up for the "lack of creativity" that he witnessed on the Prime Material. Following the lead of its master, the Honking Chaos decided to give birth to its own version of this monstrosity and created the honkimera: a hybrid between a goose, a cow and a green dragon (chosen because of the fixation that Anserath has with poisonous gasses).

Falling victim of the draconic component of its nature, a honkimera desires to hoard a treasure, but is not smart enough to understand the difference between valuables and garbage. Because of this, a honkimera's nest will be cluttered with anything: precious gems, household items, entire wagons (full or empty), broken or rotten goods, and more.

monsterFluff.name: Honkraken
entries: A honkraken is a creature from the dawn of time and a peak specimen of goosedom. In the age when the war between gods and primordials was raging, the former created the {@creature kraken||krakens} as their soldiers, while the mischievous Ur-goose gave birth to the honkrakens as a way to openly mock them. The Primordial of Havonk infused its children with the echo of its ancestral honk, and gifted them its magical plumage that protects them from heat, cold and even magic.

Even if significantly weaker than their tentacled counterparts, the honkrakens are still terrifying creatures that can (and will) spread chaos, fear and wreck with great ease. Their talent for senseless destruction is so great, that they attracted the attention (and admiration) of Anserath, the Honking Chaos itself, that gifted them with magical powers aimed at delivering even more havoc.

Nowadays, honkrakens are considered no more than a legend, or a tale from drunken sailors that nobody can (or want to) believe. However, when a storm is brewing in the open sea and the thunder in the sky mixes with an echoing honk from the depths, many start to reconsider these legends. When they do, often, it's already too late.

entries.name: A Honkraken's Lair
entries: A honkraken usually lives in a deep, narrow trench, in an underwater cave or under the surface of a sargasso island.There, they collect amounts of items that range between the legendary and the completely useless, as their avian mind doesn't comprehend the difference between treasure and trash.

images.title: An ambitious warlock of the Honking Chaos summons the power of the Honkonomicon to bind a honkraken while wielding the cane of the silly goose. His vicious goose familiar assists him in this dangerous endeavor.

monsterFluff.name: Megoosa
entries: Closely related with {@creature medusa||medusas} in terms of origin and nature, a megoosa is what happened to someone that tempered with the power of geese and somehow failed. This could be the result of a curse from the Great Golden Goose, a bad deal with Anserath or even just a mood swing from the Ur-goose. Whatever the cause, the creature's desire to manipulate the power of geese turned against it, partially transforming it into what it wanted to control. Now the megoosa tries to share this curse with whoever comes by, as it aims to turn other people into geese just as medusas would turn them into stone.

While medusas are susceptible to their own gaze reflected into mirrors, megoosas are affected by the power of the honks of geese, which can trigger a new transformation into them until they finally turn into a complete goose.
In combat, megoosas usually hold a {@item greatclub|PHB} in a pretty upset way, and can throw quills magically enhanced by chaos magic that they pick from their heads.

monsterFluff.name: Mother Goose
entries: Famous for her nursery rhymes and beloved children stories, Mother Goose is considered by many no more than a fictional character from the cover of a book of bedtime stories. However, who is acquainted with the powers of geese knows the truth: that Mother Goose is more than real. This apparently harmless granny is actually a being from the feywild that embodies some of the most protective aspects of goosedom. Her words and tales carry great magic, and they have the power to deliver teaching stories that can deeply affect who listens, or even to bring stories to life.

Mother Goose is the most sweet and comprehensive with children and good hearted beings in general, but has no hesitation to punish evildoers by hitting them with her walking cane. Every hit by her cane feels like a punishment and strikes the body as much as the morale.

items.name: Primal Honkecho
entries: Honkechoes exist since the dawn of time. In the age of the war between primordial and deities, the Ur-goose was screaming to bring destruction to its enemies or to grief the defeat of a dear member of its flock. The most intense and meaningful of these honks carried with them enough emotion and willpower to come into existence as their own creature, becoming the undying message that the Ur-goose left to the world.

monsterFluff.name: Rhonk
entries: If you hear thunder, there's a storm coming. However, if you hear a thunder that sounds like pure fowlish destruction, that's a rhonk. These titanic birds have a wingspan of almost two hundred feet, and are usually kept as pets by the most powerful giants. A rhonk that escapes its master can bring down havoc on entire kingdoms before being stopped by somebody strong (and crazy) enough to face them, its master comes to reclaim it or (more likely) the avian terror just loses interest and goes somewhere else.

Rhonks are the more clumsy, destructive and erratic cousins of {@creature roc||rocs}. Back in the days when Annam, father of all giants, created the rocs as a mean to try to level the field in the war between his children and the dragons, his vassal Memnor tried a similar effort. While Annam created a noble, reliable mount for his children, Memnor the trickster manipulated the chaotic energies of the Ur-goose to create the rhonk and gifted. Since that day, rhonks have become a favorite pet for cloud giants in particular, that consider them like a giant joke.

images.title: An adventurer flying on the wings of a rhonk

monsterFluff.name: Ur-goose
entries: The Ur-goose, also known as the Primordial Havonk, is an ancestral being who embodies natural chaos in its raw state, considered to be the first goose that ever walked on earth (even if the timeless {@creature Great Golden Goose|Honkonomicon} might have preceded it) and gave birth to several exemplars of goosekind. The Ur-goose's body is a towering 40-foot tall mass of raw elements that are perpetually swirling, shifting and mixing with each other, as they can never find a stable form. At the core of the Ur-goose lies a brilliant nebula, which is the source of its creative power.

Despite its immense size, the titan's shifting body is capable of concealing itself with great ease, usually by mixing with the elemental matter of its surrounding environment. In fact, the Primordial Havonk is renowned to be one the most clever tricksters and escapists of the multiverse. After defeating the primordials at the dawn of time, the gods have been hunting for the Ur-goose incessantly for eons, with no success. In fact, the Primordial Havonk takes great joy into seeing the frustration of other beings going on a wild goose chase to find it or catch it, often with poor or no results.

Even if the Ur-goose is often running away or hiding, there are times when it might decide to take a stance and fight back, or even to actively move war to its enemies. This is usually the case when civilization is trying to impose its "order" on an untainted natural area, or when something poses a great danger to goosekind as whole. When the Ur-goose is fighting the rules of matter, magic and reality constantly bend around its chaotic essence, while its honk has the wildest effects (both harmful and beneficial) to its enemies.
For more information on the lore, cults and powers of the Ur-goose, see {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1|Ur-goose, Primordial of Havonk}.

entries.name: Ur-goose's Lair
entries: Typically, the Ur-goose frequents the natural areas of the Prime Material that are the most far away from civilization. The Primordial Havonk changes location often to always be one step ahead of its chasers, but when it chooses a lair, it is often an untainted natural area with dense environmental features (like a tangled jungle or a complex of narrow caves) with plenty of spots to hide.

images.title: The Ur-goose in one of its many, threatening forms

monsterFluff.name: Weregoose
entries: A weregoose is an absolute agent of chaos. As humanoids, they develop longer necks, smaller eyes and thicker lips. In their humanoid forms, they prefer weapons that enable them to create the most mayhem in the shortest amount of time, like {@item greatclub|PHB|greatclubs} and {@item flail|PHB|flails}, but they are clever enough to change to a more suitable weapon if they need more finesse.
Weregeese infect other humanoids out of spite, to punish someone that misbehaved or just to create more chaos.Sometimes, they might infect somebody that they really wish to protect.
When they can, weregeese gather in very tight communities, developing strong interpersonal bonds and a great desire to protect the weakest members.
More {@variantrule Player Characters as Lycanthropes|MM|information on lycanthropes} can be found in the {@book Monster Manual|MM} .

items: Wild geese are more agile and, when in groups, fly in V-shaped formations.

legendaryGroup.name: Anserath, the Honking Chaos
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Anserath can take one of the following lair actions; it can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Festering Filth
entries: Until the next initiative count 20, creatures in the lair have disadvantage on saving throws against poison and take an extra 5 ({@damage 1d10}) poison damage whenever they take any damage from any source.

items.name: Unbearable Noise
entries: All of the demon lord's heads bicker and honk purposelessly. Until the next initiative count 20, all creatures in the lair except for Anserath are {@condition deafened}, have vulnerability to psychic damage and make Wisdom saving throws with disadvantage.

items.name: Warping Goose Heads
entries: Three demonic goose heads spawn from the ground and beak as many nearby creatures. Each target makes a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) magical piercing damage and becoming {@condition grappled} on a failed save ({@dc 18} to escape). A creature {@condition grappled} by one of these heads is eligible to be targeted by the Feed the Geese legendary action. The heads disappear when Anserath uses another lair action, freeing any creature {@condition grappled} by them.

regionalEffects: The region containing Anserath's nest is warped by its magic,creating one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Corrupted Birth
entries: Once per day, an egg hatching within 6 miles of the lair gives birth to a {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}* if Anserath wishes so. The {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon} grows to full size within one round.

items.name: Raging Geese
entries: Goose creatures within 6 miles of the lair develop violent tendencies (even more than usual) and could try to eat any other creature.

items.name: Filthy and Hungry
entries: Within 6 miles of the lair, creatures need two days of food per day to sustain themselves.Additionally, Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) checks have disadvantage, and Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks have advantage.

regionalEffects: If Anserath dies, these effects fade over the course of {@dice 1d10} days.

legendaryGroup.name: Gooseflayer Collective
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the collective can take one of the following lair actions; it can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Honking Barrier
entries: The collective casts a {@spell wall of fire} spell ({@dc 18}) that deals thunder damage instead.

items.name: Honking Pulse
entries: All creatures within 120 feet of the collective that are currently maintaining {@status concentration} on a spell take 5 ({@damage 1d10}) psychic damage and have disadvantage on the next {@status concentration} check.

items.name: Flock Intrusion
entries: Three creatures that the collective can see make a {@dc 18} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, a target becomes {@condition charmed} by the collective. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

regionalEffects: The region containing the collective's lair is influenced by its psionic energies, creating one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Goose Vision
entries: The collective can cast {@spell scrying} at will on any goose creature it can detect with its Goose Sense.

items.name: Goose Whispers
entries: The collective casts {@spell suggestion} ({@dc 18}, not limited to humanoid targets) on a goose creature that it can perceive through its Goose Sense and that is having a long rest or that is {@condition incapacitated}. It delivers the suggested command telepathically. If the goose creature succeeds on the saving throw, it becomes immune to this regional effect (but can still be targeted by the {@spell suggestion} spell of the collective in other circumstances).

items.name: Honkanoia
entries: Creatures within 5 miles of a collective feel like they are hearing a honk, even when there's no goose in the area.

regionalEffects: If the collective dies, these effects immediately end.

legendaryGroup.name: Great Golden Goose
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the Great Golden Goose can take one of the following lair actions; the Goose can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Cloud of Golden Feathers
entries: The Goose creates a cloud of golden feathers in a 20-foot radius from a point she can see. The cloud blocks line of sight, and any non-celestial creature in the area is {@condition blinded}. The spell lasts until another lair action is used, up to 1 hour.

items.name: Starry Sparkles
entries: The Goose casts the {@spell faerie fire} spell ({@dc 25}) using only verbal components and without the need to maintain {@status concentration}. The spell lasts until another lair action is used, up to 1 minute.

items.name: Stupefying Enlightenment
entries: A random creature in the lair receives prophetic vision. The target makes a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw, that it can choose to fail. On a failed save, it receives the benefits of the {@spell augury} or {@spell communion} spell (one question only) but is {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn.

regionalEffects: The territory within 5 miles of the Great Golden Goose is altered by her superior goosish influence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Golden Migration
entries: Goose creatures are attracted to the area within 5 miles of the Great Golden Goose and, once they are there, feel a reflection of her emotional state. This might or not influence the course of action of the creatures.

items.name: Honklightenment
entries: Anybody can interact with goose creatures within 5 miles of the Great Golden Goose as if they casted the {@spell speak with animal} spell.

items.name: Luck of Gold
entries: Creatures within 5 miles of the Goose that make an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) or Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check, always find precious goods or coins valuable at least {@dice 2d20} gp, or more (DM's choice). Once a creature benefits from this, it won't benefit again until the next dawn. Creatures that abuse the Luck of Gold might incur into a curse.

regionalEffects: If the Goose dies, these effects end on {@dice 1d10} days.

legendaryGroup.name: Honkraken
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), a honkraken can take one of the following lair actions; the honkraken can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Goose Alpha
entries: {@dice 1d3} creatures with the Goose tag that the honkraken can see can use their reaction to move at half speed, make an attack, or both.

items.name: Honking Confusion
entries: The {@homebrew Honkraken|[MON]} casts the {@spell confusion} spell ({@dc 18}) with only verbal component and without the need to maintain {@status concentration}. A creature that fails the saving throw is also {@condition deafened}. The spell lasts until another lair action is used, up to 1 minute.

items.name: Shonkwave
entries: Each creature within 60 feet of the honkraken makes a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw, falling {@condition prone} and being pushed 20 feet away on failure. If the target is thrown into a solid object or another creature, they both must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet the target was thrown, and be knocked {@condition prone}.

regionalEffects: The territory within 5 miles of a honkraken is altered by the creature's chaotic presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Fowlish Sightings
entries: Creatures within 5 miles of a honkraken believe that they are seeing a goose under most surfaces of water.

items.name: Goose Uprising
entries: Creatures with the Goose tag within 5 miles of a honkraken start to behave in a (even) more chaotic and violent way than usual. Regular geese start to gather as one or more {@creature flock of geese|Honkonomicon|flocks of geese}* and might attack other creatures on sight.

items.name: Storming Mood
entries: The honkraken alters the weather (always for the worse) as per the {@spell control weather} spell.

regionalEffects: If the honkraken dies, these effects immediately end.

legendaryGroup.name: Ur-goose
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the Ur-goose can take one of the following lair actions; it can't take the same lair action two rounds in a row:

items.name: Honkemental Nebula
entries: The Ur-goose casts the {@spell fog cloud} spell with only verbal component, originating from a point within its lair. Each creature that begins its turn inside the cloud takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) damage of a random type from its Honkemental Honktropy (see statblock). If the Ur-goose uses another lair action, the spell ends.

items.name: Reverse Gravity
entries: The Ur-goose casts the {@spell reverse gravity} spell ({@dc 25}) with only verbal component. This spell doesn't require {@status concentration}, but lasts only until the next initiative count 20.

items.name: Wild Magic
entries: A random {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB|wild magic effect} (see table in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}) triggers on a random creature that is within the lair.
