regionalEffects: The region containing the Ur-gooses's lair is warped by its chaotic essence, creating one or more of the following effects:

items.name: Crumble Civilization
entries: Artificial structures within 5 miles of the lair take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) force damage every 24 hours, being separated back into raw elements.

items.name: Divination Screen
entries: Casting a divination spell while within 5 miles of the lair or on a target within that area requires a successful {@dc 25} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check.

items.name: Make Geese Wild
entries: Goose creatures within 5 miles of the lair become more evasive, more violent, or both.

regionalEffects: If the Ur-goose dies, these effects instantly fade.

vehicle.name: Apparagoose of Honkish

speed.note: (or 0 ft. for both if the wing and legs aren't moving)

entries: This item first appears to be a Medium metallic egg weighing 100 pounds. The egg has a hidden engraved phrase, which can be found with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Uttering the sentence hatches the egg into a large metallic goose, with a porthole on his rear, allowing two Medium or smaller creatures to crawl inside. Ten feathers-like levers are set in a row at the far end, each in a neutral position, able to move either up or down.
To be used as a vehicle, the apparagoose requires one pilot. While the apparagoose's porthole is closed, the compartment is airtight and holds enough air for 8 hours of breathing.

The Apparagoose floats on water and can move at its land speed on it, but can't go willingly underwater. If it goes underwater it immediately shrinks back in the egg form and any passenger inside is expelled outside, in the nearest unoccupied space, suffering {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage.

A creature in the compartment can use an action to move as many as two of the apparagoose's levers up or down. After each use, a lever goes back to its neutral position. Each lever, from left to right, functions as shown in the {@table apparagoose of Honkish Levers|Honkonomicon} table.

variantrule.name: Player Characters as Weregeese
entries: A character that becomes a weregoose gains a Constitution of 12 and a Dexterity of 14 if the score isn't already higher. Attack and damage rolls for the beak are based on whichever is higher of the character's Strength and Dexterity. For the Honk action, the DC is 8 + the character's proficiency bonus + Charisma or Constitution modifier (character's choice). For more information on {@variantrule Player Characters as Lycanthropes|MM|lycanthropes as player characters}, see the {@book Monster Manual|MM}.

table.name: Apparagoose of Honkish Levers
rows: Wings and legs begin to move, allowing the apparagoose to walk and fly.
The apparagoose begins to shrink, reducing the speed to 0. When all passengers are outside it goes back in the egg form.
Side window shutters open (two per side).
Side window shutters close (two per side).
Sharp teeth extend from the apparagoose beak.
The beak with extended teeth makes the following melee weapon attack: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h} 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage.
The beak with extended teeth makes the following melee weapon attack: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h} The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}).
The apparagoose walks or fly forward.
The apparagoose walks backward or starts to float midair.
The apparagoose turns (up to) 90 degrees left.
The apparagoose turns (up to) 90 degrees right.

Powerful Honk ({@recharge 5}, only after the lever is lowered). Each creature within 10 ft., other than the apparagoose and the creatures within it, must make a Constitution saving throw (save {@dc 15}) or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage.
Gives the chance to recharge the Powerful Honk.
The apparagoose flies down 20 feet, eventually allowing it to land safely on an area of at least 10 ft. square of solid ground.
The rear porthole unseals and opens.
The rear porthole closes and seals.

table.name: Chaotic Requests
rows: Pick a fist-fight with a random humanoid and lose.

items.name: Success:
entries: You gain 1 additional chaos dice, which lasts for 8 hours, or until expended.

items.name: Failure:
entries: At random, {@dice 1d4} creatures might pick a fist-fight with you throughout the next day, regardless of their feeling towards you or if they even have fists.

items.name: Beating your Opponent:
entries: If you win the initial fist-fight, Anserath is impressed by your bloodlust; you gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls, which lasts for 8 hours. You lose this bonus as soon as you miss with an attack.

rows: Steal a shiny object worth at least 300 gp and throw it into a pond, lake, or other body of water.

items.name: Success:
entries: Anserath is pleased with the offering. You gain a +1 bonus to your saving throws for the next 8 hours.

items.name: Failure:
entries: Anserath is displeased and curses you. You immediately lose 1 chaos die. That dice remains expended until you finish a long rest.

items.name: Keeping the Item for Yourself:
entries: If you steal the item and keep it, Anserath approves of your selfish nature; You gain a +1 bonus to Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks. This bonus lasts for 8 hours, or until you lose the object, whichever comes first.

rows: Build a nest for another friendly creature.

items.name: Success:
entries: Caring for your flock is a point of pride. You gain a +2 bonus to one ability score, chosen by the friendly creature. If you attempt to influence the friendly creature's decision in any way, this becomes a −2 bonus instead. The effect lasts for 8 hours, or until you or the friendly creature falls {@condition unconscious}, whichever happens first.

items.name: Failure:
entries: You are a terrible friend and ally. For the next 8 hours, each time you roll a chaos dice, that dice's effect fails on the roll of a 6, though the dice is still expended.

items.name: Success:
entries: Anserath revels in the fear you have caused; For the next 8 hours, you know the {@spell cause fear|XGE} spell, and it doesn't count towards the number of spells you know. In addition, you can cast it once without expending a spell slot. Charisma is your spellcasting modifier for this spell.

items.name: Failure:
entries: You are a cowardly creature undeserving of Anserath's power. For the next 8 hours, you have disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws to resist being {@condition frightened}.

items.name: Success:
entries: Friends are the lifeblood of the flock. Nothing is more important. You gain a +5 bonus to Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks, which lasts for 8 hours.

items.name: Failure:
entries: Isolation is the worst thing for a goose! For the next 8 hours, whenever you make a Charisma check, roll one of your chaos dice (it is not expended). On a 1–3, you automatically fail that check, regardless of any modifiers or abilities that would say otherwise.

rows: Start a fire, or set another creature on fire.

items.name: Success:
entries: Burn it for the fury of Anserath! For the next 8 hours, you have immunity to fire damage for as long as you have at least half your hit points remaining.

items.name: Failure:
entries: Anserath demands fire! At a random point throughout the next day (determined by the DM), one random object you are carrying spontaneously catches fire, dealing {@damage 1d6} fire damage to you and every other creature within 10 feet of you. The object continues to burn until it is put out, and immediately ignites flammable objects in its vicinity.

items.name: Starting a Harmless Fire:
entries: If you create a harmless fire, such as a campfire or ignite a piece of paper, roll a {@dice 1d6}. On a 4–6, Anserath is pleased with the offering, but you only gain fire resistance, instead of immunity. On a 1–3, Anserath is insulted by the offering, and causes the fire to erupt into an inferno, which encompasses a 20-foot cube for 1 minute, or until it is put out. The inferno ignites flammable objects in its area, and any creature that begins its turn in the area or moves into the area for the first time on a turn must make a Dexterity saving throw versus your Warlock save DC, taking {@damage 5d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

table.name: Fowlish Mutations
rows: The target's feet become webbed. Its speed is halved, but gains a swim speed equal to its basic speed.

The target's head becomes the one of a goose. It can't speak or cast spells with verbal components, but can make unarmed attacks with the beak that deal {@damage 1d4} damage plus its Strength modifier
The target's arms become goose wings. The target drops everything that it's holding and has no hands anymore, but gains a flying speed of 15 feet.
The target grows oversized feathers all over its body. It has disadvantage on Dexterity checks (including initiative) but makes all saving throws against cold with advantage.

The target grows a set of hardened bone spurs on each of its elbows or wrists. These bone spurs can be used as unarmed attacks, and deal {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage plus its Strength modifier on a hit.
The target's neck becomes surprisingly long and can't sustain the head's weight anymore. The target has disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks.

The target's tongue develops oversized razor-sharp teeth. Whenever the target takes an action that requires it to swallow or speak (like drinking a potion or casting a spell with verbal components) roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the target takes {@damage 1} piercing damage.

The target's brain shrinks and becomes a goose brain. The target has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened} and disadvantage on Intelligence attack rolls, ability checks and saving throws.

table.name: Golden Goose Domain Spells
rows: {@spell conjure honkland beings|Honkonomicon}*, {@spell freedom of movement}

table.name: Goose Behaviour
rows: The goose spends its time beating its wings and honking ferociously, but takes no other action.
The goose moves up to its speed towards a hostile creature it can see and makes a beak attack against it.

The goose flies up into the air and remains there honking ferociously. All creatures (including you) that are within 30 feet of the goose and can see and hear it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw versus your ranger spell save DC or become {@condition frightened} of the goose until the end of their next turn.
The goose decides to listen to your commands, and follows them to the best of its ability.
The goose moves up to its speed and attacks the nearest creature (friend or foe) to it, hissing angrily.

The goose regains the use of its honk, makes two attacks whenever it takes the {@action attack} action, and its damage die increases to a {@dice d10}. It then moves up to its speed and attacks the nearest hostile creature it can see.

table.name: Goose-Blooded Quirks Table
rows: Your head sprouts small, fine feathers instead of conventional hair. The feathers can change colors to suit your mood, granting you advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation} and {@skill Persuasion}) checks.
Your feet are webbed like that of a duck. You have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

Your eyes are further apart than most others, granting you a wider field of vision with which to observe your surroundings and potential threats. You can't be {@status surprised} by creatures within 60 feet of you, and creatures within 60 feet of you don't get advantage on their attack rolls as a result of being hidden from you.
Your bones are less dense than usual, making you extremely lightweight, regardless of your size. You count as one size smaller for the purposes of being pulled, pushed, or lifted by another creature.

Your tongue is lined with razor-sharp teeth, granting you a taste for many otherwise unappetizing foodstuffs. You sustain yourself by eating rotting meat, small insects, raw grains, and other difficult-to-digest foodstuffs, and suffer no ill effects from ingesting them.

You secrete a hydrophobic oil, preventing your skin from becoming wet. As a result, you remain warm when wet, and you dry off completely in a matter of minutes, regardless of how wet you previously were. In addition, the lack of moisture grants you resistance to lightning damage.

You have a set of hardened bone spurs on each of your elbows or wrists. These bone spurs can be used as natural weapons, and deal {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage on a hit. You can make an additional attack with your natural weapons as a bonus action when you use your action to make a melee weapon attack, provided your hands aren't full.

At the beginning of each new dawn, you imprint on one creature or moving object you see within the first 10 minutes of waking up. You see this object or creature as a treasured friend who must be protected. The object or creature grants you a single inspiration die, which is a {@dice d6}. This die lasts for 8 hours, or until expended. When you or a treasured friend you can see within 30 feet of you would make a saving throw or an ability check, you can expend your inspiration die and roll it, adding the number rolled to the total of the saving throw or ability check. You can roll the inspiration die after the ability check or saving throw is made, but before you know the outcome.

table.name: Magic Honktems by Rarity
rows: {@item The Real Game of the Goose|Honkonomicon}

entries: Old Mother Goose,
When she wanted to wander,
Would ride through the air
On a very fine gander.
Humpty Dumpty
Sat on a Wall
Humpty Dumpty
Had a Great Fall
All the King's Horses
And All the King's Men
Couldn't Put Humpty
Together Again
Old King Cole was a merry old soul,
And a merry old soul was he;
He called for his pipe, and he called for his bowl,
And he called for his fiddlers three.
Every fiddler he had a fiddle,
And a very fine fiddle had he;
Oh there's none so rare, as can compare,
With King Cole and his fiddlers three.
Ring-a-round the rosie,
A pocket full of posies,
Ashes! Ashes!
We all fall down.
Cows in the meadows
Eating buttercups
A-tishoo! A-tishoo!
We all jump up.
Little Jack Horner
Sat in the corner,
Eating his Christmas pie;
He put in his thumb,
And pulled out a plum,
And said, "What a good boy am I!"
Wee Willie Winkie runs through the town,
Upstairs and downstairs in his night-gown,
Tapping at the window, crying at the lock,
Are the children in their bed, for it's past ten o'clock?
Baa, baa, black sheep,
Have you any wool?
Yes, sir, yes, sir,
Three bags full;
One for the master,
And one for the dame,
And one for the little boy
Who lives down the lane.
Star light, star bright,
First star I see tonight,
I wish I may, I wish I might,
Have this wish I wish tonight.

entries.name: Content Warning
entries: Some of the game components reference the rules for {@variantrule madness|DMG} from the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}.

entries.name: v.1.0 01/04/2023:
entries: first release.

entries.name: On the Cover
entries: An ambitious warlock of the Honking Chaos summons the power of the {@item Honkonomicon|Honkonomicon} to bind a {@creature honkraken|Honkonomicon} while wielding the {@item cane of the silly goose|Honkonomicon}. His vicious goose familiar assists him in this dangerous endeavor.

{@note Disclaimer: Echidna Design doesn't recommend you to summon the Urgoose in a closed space. Make sure to open all windows before dealing with goosish powers, especially if a demogoose, a feathered ooze or Anserath are involved. The crown of the flaming goose is not designed to be worn during important social events.}

entries.name: Welcome to the Honkonomicon
entries: Within these pages lies the knowledge of the power of geese and how to wield it. The Honkonomicon presents plenty of option both for the DM and the players, designed to ensure that chaos and havonk will reign supreme, because peace was definitely never an option.

entries.name: Chapter 1: Honktroduction
entries: In this first chapter you will find informations on how to best use this book. Following that, the {@book Geese of Power|Honkonomicon|1|Geese of Power} section goes in depth into the lore and powers of Anserath, the Great Golden Goose and the Ur-goose, laying the foundation for the rest of the book.

entries.name: Chapter 2: Goose Subclasses
entries: Here you will find eleven subclasses deeply tied to the geese of power and to goosekind in general. There is one subclass per each class in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} except for the druid, that you can find in {@loader Circle of the Honk|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json} (VS Press/Vall Does DnD) featuring: a druid subclass, new spells and creatures.

entries.name: Chapter 3: Goosish Magic
entries: The first section, {@book Spells of the Honk|Honkonomicon|3|Spells of the Honk}, contains sixteen spells of all levels to enable any spellcaster to wield the power of geese, while {@book Fowlish Curses|Honkonomicon|3|Fowlish Curses} proposes seven goosish curses that follow the same rules of the ones in {@book Van Richten's Guide to Ravenloft|VRGR}. The last section, {@book Magic Honktems|Honkonomicon|3|Magic Honktems}, presents sixteen magic items of all rarities (from Common to Artifact) including the {@item Honkonomicon|Honkonomicon} itself.

entries.name: Chapter 4: Goostiarium
entries: The last chapter is all dedicated to the children of the honk: goose creatures spreading from CR 0 to CR 26, including the geese of power themselves. Here you will also find some indications on how to honkify any creature, and the {@book Adventure Hoonks|Honkonomicon|4|Adventure Hoonks} section with six quest ideas involving geese, divided per tier of play.

entries.name: Other Books
entries: To use this compendium you need the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} and {@book Monster Manual|MM}.

You will find references to other books, especially {@loader Circle of the Honk by Vall Syrene|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json}. Even if having these books might give you additional insight or goosish content, you don't need them to use this compendium.

entries.name: Practice Safe Honking
entries: Before introducing the materials from the {@i Honkonomicon} in an ongoing campaign, consider the following:

items: A lot of what you will find in this book can easily introduce a certain dose of silliness in your games (and we designed it specifically for this purpose).
Some components of this book (like the {@item crown of the flaming goose|Honkonomicon} wondrous item) might enable or reinforce the chance of conflict between playing characters.
Several components of this book (like the {@spell call of the Ur-goose|Honkonomicon} spell) can introduce sudden events or random effects that can disrupt the regular flow of an adventure.

entries: The main theme of the {@i Honkonomicon} is chaos, and we designed it with that in mind. We love chaos, and we hope you do too. Nonetheless, consider how the points above will sit with your group. For example, while most players and groups enjoy a good joke here and there, this amount of silliness might not work well with a {@adventure Curse of Strahd|CoS} campaign, and conflict among characters can be an especially tricky topic for most groups.

It might be worth it to discuss these points ahead openly during session zero, or to have a new session zero about them. If you are in doubt between redoing session zero or not, it's probably better that you do so.

If that's what you need to do, feel free to adapt the description and lore of what you'll find in this book to better suit the style and aesthetic of your campaign. The Great Golden Goose will forgive you.

entries.name: Deep into the Honkverse
entries: If you wish to delve deeper into the chaotic powers of geese, you can check the DMsGuild for more books on this same theme, as:

items: {@loader Circle of the Honk by Vall Syrene|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json} (VS Press/Vall Does DnD) featuring: a druid subclass, new spells and creatures.
{@loader The Honkrasque by Paolo Davolio|creature/Echidna Design; Honkrasque.json} (Echidna Design) featuring an avian version of the tarrasque.
{@loader Honkdra by Lord of Eat|Lord of Eat; Honkdra.json}, featuring several versions of the goose-headed hydra.

entries: Of these, you can find the {@loader Honkrasque|creature/Echidna Design; Honkrasque.json} and {@link Circle of the Honk|https://www.dmsguild.com/en/product/325509/circle-of-the-honk} at a discounted price within the {@link Honkonomical Bundle|https://www.dmsguild.com/en/product/432419/the-honkonomical-bundle-bundle}.

entries.name: Anserath, the Honking Chaos
entries: Also known as the Raging Mouths, Demogorgon's Pet and the Honking Chaos, Anserath is a multi-headed abyssal horror of terrible proportions. The dissonant honks of its several avian maws echo through the whole Abyss, making smaller fiends shiver and powerful demons shake their heads in concern.

entries.name: Chaos and Rage
entries: Of the three Geese of Power, Anserath is the one that embodies chaos in the most destructive way. The chaotic nature of the Abyss itself flows in its essence, making it impossible to reliably foresee anything about its behavior. Its decisions make no sense, and its actions have no purpose other than delivering wreckage on everything that surrounds it. At the same time, Anserath is absolutely filled with a kind of unstoppable, contagious rage that makes it an opponent impossible to reason with.

Even in the Abyss, other demons mostly treat the Honking Chaos as something that should be left alone (or to run away from). It has the habit of randomly appearing on the field of major battles between demonic armies, causing chaos and confusion among both sides in completely unforeseeable ways.

entries.name: Demon's Pet and Feral Fiend
entries: Originally, Anserath was created by Pazuzu, flying lord of the abyssal skies, as a tool to spread extreme destruction and confusion on its enemies. However, right after being set loose towards its first battle, the Honking Chaos became completely impossible to control and went on its own way, with terrible mayhem for all sides involved.

Right after that, {@creature Demogorgon|MTF} himself claimed Anserath as his own guardian beast and pet, as the two found significant kinship in their mutual madness and primordial chaotic nature. For eons, the Raging Mouths accompanied the Prince of Demons in battle and kept him company in their shared lair, to the point of becoming known as Demogorgon's Pet.

However, not even the twin-headed demon lord had the ability to tame such a creature forever. Eventually, Anserath ran away from its master to never come back, glad to let loose its rage on any being encountered without restrictions. It is said that Demogorgon's paranoia played a role in this decision, even if Anserath's unpredictable nature might be enough of an explanation.

In more recent times, the Honking Chaos has been sighted mostly roaming around Yeenoghu's Realm, especially in the outskirts of the Seeping Woods. The Prince of Gnolls seems to be proud to call the demon a guest of its realm, and formally considers Anserath as a vassal, even if no such official claim has been made. As opposed to what {@creature Demogorgon|MTF} did, {@creature Yeenoghu|MTF} seems to understand and respect the Raging Mouths as a creature of its own: not a pet, but a savage beast with a wild nature that just can't be tamed. Yeenoghu's followers are taught to not bother Anserath or engage it during combat, and to get out of its way when it's "hunting" (more like "purposelessly destroying"). At the same time, the troops of the Prince of Gnolls (or the Prince himself) often follow after Anserath's, taking advantage of the mayhem left behind while trying to not catch too much of its attention.

Another location where The Honking Chaos can often be spotted is the Endless Maze, the layer of the Abyss that {@creature Baphomet|MTF} claims as his home. The two beast-shaped demon lords seem to enjoy repeatedly fighting each other, and they have a relationship that walks the line between friends and foes.

entries.name: Cultists of the Honking Chaos
entries: Anserath's followers are typically violent beings who love to challenge the status quo by using extreme, unmotivated violence. The demon lord can be a patron for the {@class Warlock|PHB|warlocks of the pact of the honking chaos|Honking Chaos|Honkonomicon} (see {@book Chapter 2|Honkonomicon|2}).
His favorite followers gain the Barbed Tongue trait, the Fiendish Honk trait, or both.

items.name: Barbed Tongue
entries: The creature has a long, barbed tongue that can be used for unarmed attacks or to {@action grapple} a target. The barbed tongue deals {@damage 1d6} piercing damage plus the creature's Dexterity or Strength modifier and the creature is proficient with it.

items.name: Fiendish Honk (Recharges after a Long Rest)
entries: This creature emits an otherworldly honk that strikes fear and confusion in the hearts of its enemies. Each target chosen by the creature that is within 30 feet of it and can hear the creature makes a Wisdom saving throw, with {@dc 8} + the creature's Charisma modifier + the creature's proficiency bonus. On a failure, each target becomes {@condition frightened} until the end of the target's next turn and uses its reaction to move at its speed in a random direction.

entries.title: A cultist of the Honking Chaos ignites filthy green flames for his lord Anserath

entries.name: The Great Golden Goose
entries: Geese are a recurrent presence in several fables and fairytales, either physically (like the goose of the golden feathers or the golden egg) or metaphorically (like Mother Goose and her nursery rhymes). In these stories geese represent luck, prosperity and care, but they also embody a "morale of the story" that rewards the virtuous and punishes the greedy. These creatures and concepts share the same origin and inspiration: the Great Golden Goose, a celestial whose transcendent powers trace back to the dawn of the multiverse.

Also known as the Mother of Gold, the Cosmic Migrator or even just "the Goose", she delivers presents and good fortune to whomever she deems worthy, and fowlish curses to those who try to exploit the good will of her gifts.

entries.name: Honkcestral Origins
entries: Nobody knows who or why the Great Golden Goose was first created: she simply exists and always existed, being a manifestation of the multiverse's chaotic necessity to exercise freedom in the purpose of searching for its own ultimate meaning. Therefore, the Goose and the egg that created her always existed, both at the same time. Nobody knows which one came first, or even if the Goose will ever meet her end.

If the Ur-goose embodies chaos in its raw (and mostly destructive) state, the Mother of Gold incarnates its softest facets instead: freedom of body, mind and spirit, and the chance for any being (even the most unlikely and humble one) to turn the tides of its own destiny. However, her chaotic nature can also manifest in the shape of a particularly vengeful nature, easy to anger and very dangerous, especially when faced by greed and selfishness or when she needs to protect her flock.

entries.name: Migration of the Mind
entries: The Goose's purpose is to search for the most ambitious of all answers: the meaning of the multiverse. In her quest to resolve the ultimate question, she periodically visits several locations of the Upper Planes, the Feywild and the Astral Sea. Most of the time, her travel is like a cycle that brings her always to the same locations, making it similar to a migration. Every once in a while, the Goose might suddenly change her migration path, visiting other planar destinations or even the Prime Material. When this happens, her followers always consider it as a sign that something portentous (either positive or negative) is about to happen.

Because of her repeated migrations in search for knowledge and ancestral origin, the Mother of Gold is considered one of the wisest beings of the multiverse. There are many that approach her temples, or even the Goose herself, looking for enlightenment or for answers that can't be found anywhere else. However, the Goose is mostly enigmatic and abstracted from reality: she only expresses herself in divine honks, that need to be interpreted by sages that are proficient into the fowlish powers.

entries.name: The Golden Flock
entries: The Goose owes the title of "Mother of Gold" both to her prolificacy and to her nature. All of the {@creature Goose of the Golden Feathers|Honkonomicon|geese of the golden feathers} (see {@book Chapter 4: Goostarium|Honkonomicon|4}) descend directly from her,therefore she's responsible for the existence of all of the golden eggs in the world. Additionally, it is believed that the {@item Golden Egg of Divinity|Honkonomicon|Divine Golden Egg} (see {@book Chapter 3: Goosish Magic|Honkonomicon|3|Magic Honktems}) is none other than her own original, true egg, or at least an egg directly laid from her.

In a wider sense, the Mother of Gold considers as part of her flock any humble creature that has been afflicted by misfortune but never turned to evil or darkness because of the hardness of life. When her transcendent sight falls on a humble spirit that needs help, she might send one of her {@creature Goose of the Golden Feathers|Honkonomicon|geese of the golden feathers} to lay one or more golden eggs for it, or to guide a worthy being to a brighter future.

Even if the Great Golden Goose is not a proper deity, her transcended enlightenment can act as a medium between divine powers and the mortals who share her ideals and nature. Therefore, several temples are built in her name, and she delivers power to the {@class Cleric|PHB|clerics of the Golden Goose Domain|Golden Goose|Honkonomicon} (see {@book Chapter 2|Honkonomicon|2}).

At the same time, the Mother of Gold is considered an inspiration by many {@class Paladin|PHB|paladins of the Oath of the Righteous Gander|Righteous Gander|Honkonomicon} (see {@book Chapter 2|Honkonomicon|2}) and can act as patron for some {@class Warlock|PHB|celestial warlocks|Celestial|XGE} (see {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE} and the additional invocations in {@book Chapter 2|Honkonomicon|2} of this book).

entries.name: Gifts of Gold
entries: Here are some examples of the supernatural gifts that the Great Golden Goose could deliver to a servant or to a worthy mortal, and a recommended level for each of them (see {@book Chapter 7|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts} for rules about Supernatural Gifts):

entries.title: A holy symbol of the Great Golden Goose

entries.name: Ur-goose, Primordial of Havonk
entries: Ancient entity of chaos, confusion and general mischief, the Ur-goose is a primordial creature that embodies the more disorderly aspects of the natural world. It is the most pure and primal representation of goosedom in the absolute sense.

As druids would teach you, nature knows no ethics or morality, finding its own purpose in itself: the gentle breeze that spreads the seeds and the terrifying storms that eradicate the trees both belong to the same unity, and nature doesn't perceive one or the other as right or wrong. Disarray and havoc also have a place in the natural balance, and the Ur-goose embodies them perfectly.

entries.name: Wild Goose Chase
entries: In the time when deities and primordials were at war to establish who was gonna be the true ruler, the Ur-goose expressed no interest in that conflict. Instead, it took great enjoyment into acting mischievously towards both sides, playing as a wildcard into several battles or just throwing off everybody's plans for the sake of it.

Following the fall of their enemies, several deities have been looking for the Primordial of Havonk in every corner of the Prime Material, going on a literal goose hunt to find it and make sure that it couldn't act against them. However it was never possible to catch it or defeat it, as the Ur-goose is too unpredictable. Additionally, some deities of mischief took sympathy into their prey and started sabotaging in secret the efforts to find it.

With the eons passing, deities abandoned their wild goose chase and found a way to come to terms with the fact that the Primordial of Havonk will always be out there somewhere, potentially throwing off their plans and messing things up. Some sages have been proposing that this might be one of the (main) reasons why many deities left the Prime Material in favor of the Outer Planes.

entries.name: Monstrous Mother Goose
entries: One of the favorite occupations of the Ur-goose is to design (if you can call it so) and give birth to creatures made in its image and resemblance, to make sure that disorder can be spread in each and every corner of the multiverse. Sometimes this is done in plain despise of the products of other creator entities, as a form of mocking. Many are its creations and they come in all shapes and sizes, as the terrifying {@creature honkdra|Honkonomicon}, the insidious {@creature honkatrice|Honkonomicon} or the dreadful {@creature honkraken|Honkonomicon}.

All of the progenies of the Primordial of Havonk have one thing in common: they are designed to be agents of disorder. Some bring chaos through mischief, and others through literal destruction. Either way, the world soon learned to never trust a goose.

entries.name: Enemy of Civilization
entries: Even if the Primordial of Havonk is neither a deity or a leader, there are organizations and individuals believing in what it represents and embodies. Several druidic circle sworship the Ur-goose and consider it their protective spirit. Usually, those are the ones actively working to fight back civilization, and so they look up to what they consider the incarnation of the most chaotic aspects of nature. By worshiping the Ur-goose, these druidic circles aim to be inspired for new and creative ways to disrupt the advancements of organized society, and to ensure that it doesn't threaten the purity of the wild world.

entries.name: Gifts of Havonk
entries: Here are some examples of the supernatural gifts that the Ur-goose could deliver to a worthy bringer of havonk, and a recommended level for each one of them (see {@book Chapter 7|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts} for rules about Supernatural Gifts):

entries.name: Charm of the Wild Goose Chase

entries.title: A settlement set on fire for the will of the Primordial of Havonk

data.name: Chapter 2: Goose Subclasses
entries: In the following pages you will find eleven subclasses revolving around geese. There is one per each class presented in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} except for the {@class druid|PHB}, which you can find in {@loader Circle of the Honk|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json}.

entries.title: A Feather Bard showing his performing skills

entries.name: Cleric: Domain of the Golden Goose
Monk: Way of the Wild Goose

entries.title: A symbol of the Oath of the Righteous Gander

entries.name: Additional Eldritch Invocations
entries: The Pact of the Honking Chaos grants you additional Eldritch Invocation options, in addition to those found in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}. See the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} for more information on how Eldritch Invocations work.

entries.title: The Ur-goose in one of its many, threatening forms

entries.name: Spells of the Honk
entries: In this section you will find sixteen spells for all levels and classes, each representing a particular manifestation of the power of goosekind. Several of these spells recall the geese of power from {@book Chapter 1|Honkonomicon|1}, or are even reflections or extensions of their supernatural peculiarities.
For more spells about geese, see {@loader Circle of the Honk|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json} on DMsGuild.

entries.name: Wielding the Honking Magic
entries: The DM can consider to make these spells available in one of the following ways:

items: The characters can freely choose these spells at any time.

One or more of these spells are introduced through scrolls, tomes or other magic items (like the {@item honkarina|Honkonomicon} or even the {@item Honkonomicon|Honkonomicon} artifact itself). After being discovered, they can be picked by any character that has access to these items.

Certain powerful goose creatures can teach one or more of these spells as a reward to the characters, or just for the sake of adding more chaos to the world. The DM could reward the use of a certain spell as a charm first (see {@book Chapter 7|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts}), then the character that received the charm could eventually learn the spell when leveling up, or substitute a spell that the character already knows with it.

entries.name: Fowlish Curses
entries: The Geese of Power and their creatures are whimsical and vengeful beings, often easy to anger. To make things worse, they usually have a chaotic sense of humor that often gets mixed up with their sense of justice (when they have any).

The following curses can be laid as a trap, a punishment or a consequence of seriously crossing one of the Geese of Power. They are intended more as a way to mess up with the characters, than as a critical danger. Spells at the characters' disposal might relieve these curses' effects temporarily but can't lift them completely.

A {@spell remove curse} spell cast on the victim of such a curse suppresses the burden for 1 hour. A {@spell greater restoration} spell suppresses the burden until the victim finishes a long rest. Death usually ends a curse, but the curse returns in full force if the cursed character returns to life without resolving the curse. If you want to read more information about this kind of curse, see {@book Van Richten's Guide to Ravenloft|VRGR}.

entries.title: The fabled curse of the golden feathers at work
A peasant finds a golden goose in a cut tree

entries.name: Magic Honktems
entries: In the following pages you will find several magic items related to the geese of power, Mother Goose, or to other aspects of goose existence.

entries.name: Variant: Circle of the Honk Spells
entries: If you own {@loader Circle of the Honk|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json}, add all spells from that book to the Spell feature of the {@item Honkonomicon|Honkonomicon} artifact. Casting one of these spells costs 1 charge per spell level.

entries.name: The Real Game of the Goose
Totally Normal Goose Figurine (Figurine of Wondrous Power)

data.name: Chapter 4: Goostarium

entries.title: An adventurer flying on the wings of a rhonk

entries: In these pages you will find several specimens of goosekind that the characters can fight, befriend or tame (or die trying), ranging from the humble {@creature domestic goose|Honkonomicon} to the geese of power themselves.
For more goose creatures, see the {@loader Honkrasque|creature/Echidna Design; Honkrasque.json} and {@loader Circle of the Honk|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json} on DMsGuild.

entries.name: Goose Creatures (Goose Tag)
entries: For the purpose of this book, a "goose creature" is a creature with the Goose tag. Several components of this book refer to goose creatures, like the spell {@creature conjure honkland beings|Honkonomicon} or the {@item Honkonomicon|Honkonomicon} artifact. You will see that all of the creatures in the following pages have the Goose tag, except for the fabled {@creature Mother Goose|Honkonomicon}.

The DM could expand the Goose tag to creatures from other books when it makes sense to do so, such as for the monster from {@loader Circle of the Honk|collection/Vall Syrene; Circle of the Honk.json}.

entries.name: Honkify Your Monster
entries: If you wish so, you can turn a monster into its goose-related version by changing its physical appearance and behavior and adding the Goose tag to it. Here's some examples:

entries.name: Goosicorn (Unicorn)
entries: If you roam in an enchanted forest, you might encounter one of the sacred children of the Great Golden Goose: the legendary goosicorn. This celestial giant goose can manifest its shimmering shield with a holy honk, and attacks with its wings just as hard as a {@creature unicorn} would with its hooves.

entries.name: Honkering Beaker (Gibbering Mouther)
entries: When the energies of the Far Realm contaminate the powers of goosekind, the result can be a goose-shaped {@creature gibbering mouther} called a honkering beaker. This goosish aberration has a multitude of beaks that express its gibbering ability as a cacophony of honks.

entries.name: Vronk (Vrock)
entries: A {@creature vrock} demon that belongs to Anserath's following is called a vronk. Its head and beak resembles more of a goose than a {@creature vulture}, and its stunning screech sounds like a high-pitched honk.

entries.name: Magical Attacks and Damage
entries: Instead of writing the {@b Magical Weapons} ability in the statblocks, we have chosen to indicate if an attack deals magical bludgeoning, piercing or slashing damage in the text of the attack itself, like in the following example "19 ({@damage 2d10 + 8}) magical piercing damage". For all intents and purposes, consider a creature with this kind of wording inits stat block as having the {@b Magical Weapons} ability.

entries.credit: Polina Sokolova, edited by Simone Malvezzi

entries.title: Sir Goose on his faithful giant goose steed

An ambitious warlock of the Honking Chaos summons the power of the Honkonomicon to bind a honkraken while wielding the cane of the silly goose. His vicious goose familiar assists him in this dangerous endeavor.

entries.name: Adventure Hoonks
entries: The following quest ideas include some of the creatures from the pages above, as well as other elements and from this book.

entries.name: Night of the Goosish Deads
entries: Lately, a local farmer has been noticing more and more of his geese disappearing. Yesterday night, the farmer found that several of his geese are back, but they are now {@creature goose skeleton|Honkonomicon|goose skeletons}* that attack him or anything else (including the characters) on sight. Even so, the skeletons are friendly towards the geese of their own former flock and they act just like regular geese, as if they never left the flock.

Following the tracks of the skeletons leads the party to the hideout of a necromancer, that planned to raise a flock of undead geese. Things went wrong when the necromancer successfully summoned a {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}* but lost control of it, leading to the necromancer's death. The hideout is still full of {@creature goose skeleton|Honkonomicon|goose skeletons}*, {@creature goose zombie|Honkonomicon|goose zombies}* and the dreaded {@creature demogoose|Honkonomicon}* itself.

entries.name: When Things Go Swine
entries: A local aristocrat lady woke up to realize that her daughter, who was supposed to get married the day after, is missing. Instead, there is a violent boar in her bedroom, still dressed as the daughter, and a small wooden flask with a label saying "Goose Wine" on the floor. The boar is actually the betrothed daughter, that drank a cursed {@item goose wine|Honkonomicon}* potion created to turn the victim into a boar indefinitely. The daughter drank it as part of a bet with a foreigner, that was actually a {@creature druid} devoted to the {@creature Ur-goose|Honkonomicon}.

The {@creature druid} transformed the daughter as part of a plan go get revenge against the mother, who has plans to expand the city at the expense of the surrounding woods and swamps. The {@creature druid} is accompanied by a {@creature giant goose|Honkonomicon}, and has the obedience of a {@creature flock of geese|Honkonomicon} that faithfully guards the wilderness.

The {@creature druid} always carries the antidote to reverse the transformation. The characters could solve this in many ways, like taking the antidote by force, stealth, or trying to strike a deal between the {@creature druid} and the lady.

entries.name: Gaze of the Megoosa
entries: The {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon} from the local temple of the {@creature Great Golden Goose|Honkonomicon}, which was worshiped as a living saint, recently disappeared in a mysterious battle that killed half of the people in the temple. At the same time, people have been disappearing in the city, and after they do, a {@creature domestic goose|Honkonomicon}* eventually goes to their house in their place.

After some research, the characters can discover that this is the doing of a {@creature megoosa|Honkonomicon}* that recently established her lair nearby the city. The cursed monstrosity also has a {@creature honkimera|Honkonomicon}* doing her bidding, which she deployed to kidnap the {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon}: the {@creature megoosa|Honkonomicon} knows that the power of the golden goose can revert her transformations, but doesn't dare to kill it because is too afraid of being cursed again.
If the {@creature megoosa|Honkonomicon} is not stopped, she will keep transforming everyone in the city and province, until it becomes populated by people just as cursed as she is.

entries.name: The Child of Mother Goose
entries: The director of a local orphanage, a sweet granny known as {@creature Mother Goose|Honkonomicon}, recently disappeared after visiting one of her "children" (an orphan that grew up and left her institution along time ago). Without her, the orphanage will lose its only patron and might eventually be forced to close.

{@creature Mother Goose|Honkonomicon} is being forcefully held by a {@creature gray honker|Honkonomicon}* that she nurtured many years ago. The honker, afraid to loose her granny again, refuses to let her go. Even if {@creature Mother Goose|Honkonomicon} is actually a strong magical being in disguise, the {@creature gray honker|Honkonomicon} is now immune to her magical influence after being exposed to it for its whole childhood.

{@creature Mother Goose|Honkonomicon} wishes to be freed, and will fight alongside the characters (aiding them with her magic) as long as they don't try to kill "her child". She will reward the characters with a {@creature cane of the silly goose|Honkonomicon}* and other treasures if they manage to free her without killing the honker.

If the characters fail or abandon the quest, the {@creature gray honker|Honkonomicon} will eventually kill {@creature Mother Goose|Honkonomicon} by accident, then go into a crazy rampage and lay waste to the whole region.

entries.name: On the Wings of the Rhonk
entries: A {@creature rhonk|Honkonomicon}* has been sighted in the region recently. Shortly after, the immense monstrosity started wreaking havoc by several major cities. When the characters approach it, they will notice that the {@creature rhonk|Honkonomicon} is wearing saddle, harnesses and emblems, all proofs that the creature actually belongs to a cloud giant lord.

Truth is, the {@creature rhonk|Honkonomicon} escaped from its master's leash. If the characters kill the {@creature rhonk|Honkonomicon}, they will anger the giant lord that will go out of his way to hurt the characters and make their lives impossible. On the other hand, if the characters find away to tame or capture the creature, its master will greatly compensate them. Once tamed, the {@creature rhonk|Honkonomicon} could even bring the characters back to its owner.

The giant lord lives in a castle in the clouds, high in the sky, and is obsessed with geese. He owns a {@creature goose of the golden feathers|Honkonomicon}* that can lay golden eggs, as well as several magic items related to geese. He's also looking for a copy of the {@item Honkonomicon|Honkonomicon} artifact.

entries.name: The Lost Egg
entries: On a big island in the middle of the ocean lies the great Kingdhonk of Goonitch, where geese and humanoids lived in perfect harmony... Until now. Recently, the {@item Golden Egg of Divinity|Honkonomicon} has been stolen from the local Cathedral of the {@creature Great Golden Goose|Honkonomicon}, and from that moment the peace between humanoids and goosekind was broken. The theft angered the Mother of Gold, who is now laying her curses on the Kingdhonk and driving several goose creatures crazy. Now, chaos reigns everywhere.
The Egg was actually stolen by a {@creature honkraken|Honkonomicon}, but was bribed by the king himself to do so: he desires the Egg only for himself.

entries.name: Embrace the Havonk
entries: The Honkonomicon awaits you in all of its dangerous, goosy glory with 80 pages of options for DMs and characters.
The time of humanoids is over, the age of geese has arrived.
Peace was never an option, so honk on.
For use with the fifth edition {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, {@book Monster's Manual|MM} and {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}.
